objectives: Learn common words for things, places, and people at school.
Use new words to make simple sentences about school.
Understand and say school words clearly.

sections.text: These are the main tools, furniture, and other items you use and see in your classroom and carry to school.

examples.label: Pen
examples.value: A tool for writing with ink. It comes in different colors like blue, black, and red.

examples.label: Pencil
examples.value: A tool for writing and drawing with graphite. Marks can be erased.

examples.label: Eraser
examples.value: A small piece of rubber used to remove pencil marks from paper.

examples.label: Sharpener
examples.value: A small tool with a blade used to make a pencil's point sharp.

examples.label: Chalk
examples.value: A small stick, usually white, used by teachers to write on the blackboard.

examples.label: Crayon
examples.value: A stick of colored wax used for drawing and coloring pictures.

examples.label: Marker
examples.value: A felt-tip pen that comes in many bright colors, sometimes used on whiteboards.

examples.label: Ink
examples.value: The colored liquid inside a pen.

examples.label: Glue
examples.value: A sticky substance used to make things stick together, like paper.

examples.label: Stapler
examples.value: A device used to join sheets of paper together with a small metal staple.

examples.label: Book
examples.value: A set of pages with words and pictures, used for reading and learning.

examples.label: Notebook
examples.value: A book with blank or ruled pages for writing notes.

examples.label: Paper
examples.value: A thin, flat material used for writing or drawing on.

examples.label: Chart
examples.value: A large sheet of paper with information, diagrams, or pictures, used for teaching.

examples.label: Map
examples.value: A drawing of an area like a country or village, showing its features.

examples.label: Blackboard / Whiteboard
examples.value: A large, smooth surface on a wall where the teacher writes with chalk or markers.

examples.label: Notice Board / Bulletin Board
examples.value: A board on a wall where announcements and important information are posted.

examples.label: File
examples.value: A folder or box for holding loose papers together.

examples.label: Register
examples.value: A book used by the teacher to record students' attendance.

examples.label: Desk
examples.value: A table in the classroom where students sit to study and write.

examples.label: Chair
examples.value: A seat for one person to sit on. You sit on a chair at your desk.

examples.label: Bench
examples.value: A long seat for several students.

examples.label: Table
examples.value: A piece of furniture where the teacher keeps their books and materials.

examples.label: Cupboard
examples.value: A piece of furniture used for storing books, chalk, and other supplies.

examples.label: Dustbin
examples.value: A container for waste and rubbish to keep the classroom clean.

examples.label: Fan
examples.value: An electric device with rotating blades that circulates air to keep the room cool.

examples.label: Light
examples.value: An electric device, like a tube light or bulb, that provides light in the classroom.

examples.label: Door
examples.value: An opening in the wall that you use to enter or leave the classroom.

examples.label: Window
examples.value: An opening in the wall, usually with glass, that lets in light and air.

examples.label: Clock
examples.value: An instrument on the wall that shows the time.

examples.label: School Bag
examples.value: A bag used to carry your books, notebooks, and other school supplies.

examples.label: Lunch Box
examples.value: A box used to carry your lunch to school.

examples.label: Water Bottle
examples.value: A container used to carry drinking water to school.

examples.label: Pencil Box
examples.value: A small case used to store your pens, pencils, eraser, and other stationery.

examples.label: Ruler
examples.value: A flat, straight tool used to draw straight lines and measure length.

examples.label: Duster
examples.value: A piece of cloth or felt used to wipe off chalk marks from the blackboard.

examples.label: Bell
examples.value: An object that makes a ringing sound to signal the start or end of a class.

examples.label: Uniform
examples.value: The special set of clothes worn by all students in a school.

examples.label: Globe
examples.value: A model of the Earth shaped like a ball, with a map of the world on it.

usage_examples: I use a blue pen to write my notes.
Please sharpen your pencil before the exam.
Use glue to stick the picture in your notebook.
Please open your English book to page ten.
The teacher wrote the homework on the blackboard.
The exam schedule is on the notice board.
Keep your books on the desk.
The new books are kept in the cupboard.
Throw the pencil shavings in the dustbin.
The clock on the wall shows it is time for the lunch break.
My school bag is very heavy today.
My mother packed my favorite food in my lunch box.
Use a ruler to underline the heading.
The monitor cleaned the blackboard with a duster.
All students must come to school in a clean uniform.

sections.text: These are the main rooms, buildings, open areas, and other locations you can find at a school.

examples.label: Classroom
examples.value: The main room where students attend lessons.

examples.label: Library
examples.value: A quiet room filled with books for reading and borrowing.

examples.label: Laboratory (Lab)
examples.value: A special room for science experiments.

examples.label: Computer Room
examples.value: A room with many computers for students to learn computer skills.

examples.label: Office
examples.value: The place where the principal and administrative staff work.

examples.label: Principal's Office
examples.value: The personal office of the head of the school.

examples.label: Staffroom
examples.value: A room for teachers to use when they are not teaching.

examples.label: Auditorium / Assembly Hall
examples.value: A large hall for school functions, performances, and assemblies.

examples.label: Music Room
examples.value: A room with musical instruments where music classes are taught.

examples.label: Art Room
examples.value: A room equipped with supplies for drawing, painting, and other art activities.

examples.label: Playground
examples.value: An open outdoor area for playing games.

examples.label: Field
examples.value: A large open area, often covered with grass, used for sports.

examples.label: Garden
examples.value: An area of land with grass and flowers, planted for beauty.

examples.label: Canteen
examples.value: A place where students and staff can buy snacks and lunch.

examples.label: Gymnasium (Gym)
examples.value: A large room or hall for physical education and indoor sports.

examples.label: Sports Room
examples.value: A room where sports equipment is stored.

examples.label: Cycle Stand / Parking Lot
examples.value: An area where bicycles or other vehicles are parked.

examples.label: Stage
examples.value: A raised platform where performances are given.

examples.label: Gate
examples.value: The main entrance to the school grounds.

examples.label: Hallway / Corridor
examples.value: A long, narrow passage connecting rooms.

examples.label: Stairs
examples.value: A set of steps leading from one floor to another.

examples.label: Toilet / Washroom
examples.value: A room with a toilet and facilities for washing hands.

examples.label: Clinic / Sick Room
examples.value: A room where sick or injured students can get first aid and rest.

examples.label: Drinking Fountain / Water Cooler
examples.value: A device that provides drinking water.

examples.label: Store Room
examples.value: A room for storing unused items.

examples.label: Locker
examples.value: A small cupboard where a student can keep their personal items.

examples.label: Lost and Found
examples.value: A place where lost items are kept for their owners to claim.

examples.label: Courtyard
examples.value: An open space surrounded by school buildings.

examples.label: Podium
examples.value: A small stand from where a speaker gives a speech.

examples.label: Bookstore
examples.value: A shop in the school that sells books and stationery.

usage_examples: Our classroom is on the first floor.
We must be silent in the library.
We conduct experiments in the science lab.
The annual function will be held in the auditorium.
Children love to play on the swings in the playground.
I will eat my lunch in the canteen today.
The guard closes the school gate at 8:00 AM.
Please don't run in the hallway.
We must keep the school washroom clean.
If you feel sick, go to the sick room.
I found my lost water bottle at the lost and found.
You can buy new notebooks from the school bookstore.

sections.text: These are the various people—staff, students, and helpers—who make up the school community.

examples.label: Principal / Headmaster
examples.value: The head of the school who manages everything.

examples.label: Vice Principal
examples.value: The person who assists the principal.

examples.label: Teacher
examples.value: A person who teaches lessons and helps students learn.

examples.label: Class Teacher
examples.value: The main teacher responsible for a particular class.

examples.label: Subject Teacher
examples.value: A teacher who teaches a specific subject.

examples.label: Coordinator
examples.value: A teacher who manages a specific section of the school.

examples.label: Counselor
examples.value: A person who provides advice and support to students.

examples.label: Librarian
examples.value: The person who manages the school library.

examples.label: Lab Assistant
examples.value: A person who helps in the laboratory.

examples.label: Office Clerk
examples.value: A person who does administrative work in the school office.

examples.label: Accountant
examples.value: The person who manages the school's finances and fees.

examples.label: Student
examples.value: A person who studies and learns in a school.

examples.label: Classmate
examples.value: A fellow student who is in the same class as you.

examples.label: Friend
examples.value: A classmate or schoolmate you know well and like.

examples.label: Monitor
examples.value: A student chosen to help the teacher manage the class.

examples.label: Senior
examples.value: A student who is in a higher class than you.

examples.label: Junior
examples.value: A student who is in a lower class than you.

examples.label: Peon / Cleaner
examples.value: A staff member who helps keep the school clean and runs errands.

examples.label: Guard / Watchman
examples.value: A person who guards the school to ensure safety.

examples.label: Gardener
examples.value: A person who takes care of the school's garden and plants.

examples.label: Driver
examples.value: The person who drives the school bus.

examples.label: Canteen Staff
examples.value: The people who cook and sell food in the canteen.

examples.label: Parent
examples.value: A mother or father of a student.

examples.label: Sports Teacher / Coach
examples.value: A teacher who trains students in sports.

examples.label: Music Teacher
examples.value: A teacher who teaches how to sing or play instruments.

examples.label: Art Teacher
examples.value: A teacher who teaches drawing and craft.

examples.label: Dance Teacher
examples.value: A teacher who teaches different forms of dance.

examples.label: Visitor
examples.value: Someone who comes to the school for a short time.

examples.label: Inspector
examples.value: An official who visits the school to check its quality.

examples.label: Prefect
examples.value: A senior student who is given some authority to help maintain discipline.

examples.label: Alumnus
examples.value: A former student of the school.

usage_examples: The principal gave a speech at the assembly.
Our teacher is very kind and helpful.
The librarian helps us find good books to read.
A good student always respects their teachers.
My classmate lent me his pen today.
The monitor wrote the names of noisy students on the board.
The cleaner is sweeping the corridor.
The guard at the gate checks everyone's ID card.
My parents are coming for the parent-teacher meeting.
Our sports coach is training the football team.
The art teacher showed us how to mix colors.
A visitor came to our class to give a talk on cleanliness.
The school prefects helped manage the crowd during the event.

sections.text: These are common actions (verbs) that students, teachers, and staff perform at school.

examples.label: Learn
examples.value: To get new knowledge or skills.

examples.label: Study
examples.value: To spend time learning about a subject.

examples.label: Read
examples.value: To look at and understand written words.

examples.label: Write
examples.value: To make letters or words on paper.

examples.label: Listen
examples.value: To pay attention to sounds or words.

examples.label: Understand
examples.value: To know the meaning of something.

examples.label: Ask
examples.value: To put a question to someone.

examples.label: Answer
examples.value: To say or write something as a reply.

examples.label: Solve
examples.value: To find the correct answer to a problem.

examples.label: Memorize
examples.value: To learn something so you can remember it.

examples.label: Revise
examples.value: To study again to prepare for an exam.

examples.label: Submit
examples.value: To give your completed work to the teacher.

examples.label: Sit
examples.value: To rest your body on a chair or bench.

examples.label: Stand
examples.value: To be upright on your feet.

examples.label: Line up / Queue
examples.value: To form a line.

examples.label: Share
examples.value: To give a portion of something to others.

examples.label: Help
examples.value: To assist or support someone.

examples.label: Talk / Speak
examples.value: To communicate using words.

examples.label: Follow
examples.value: To obey a rule or instruction.

examples.label: Participate
examples.value: To take part in an activity.

examples.label: Play
examples.value: To engage in an activity for enjoyment.

examples.label: Borrow
examples.value: To take something with the intention of returning it.

examples.label: Return
examples.value: To give something back to its owner.

examples.label: Greet
examples.value: To say hello or welcome someone.

examples.label: Teach
examples.value: To give lessons and instruct students.

examples.label: Explain
examples.value: To make something clear and easy to understand.

examples.label: Check / Mark
examples.value: To look at students' work to see if it is correct.

examples.label: Demonstrate
examples.value: To show how something is done.

examples.label: Supervise
examples.value: To watch over an activity or a group of people.

examples.label: Encourage
examples.value: To give someone support, confidence, or hope.

examples.label: Announce
examples.value: To make a public statement about something.

examples.label: Organize
examples.value: To arrange or plan an event or activity.

examples.label: Ring (the bell)
examples.value: To cause a bell to make a sound.

usage_examples: We learn new things at school every day.
You must study hard to get good marks.
Listen carefully when the teacher is speaking.
Raise your hand if you want to ask something.
I can solve this maths problem easily.
Please submit your homework by Friday.
Students line up for the morning prayer.
It's good to share your lunch with your friends.
You must follow the school rules.
She always participates in class discussions.
You must return the library book on time.
We should always greet our teachers.
Our teacher teaches us with great patience.
The teacher is checking our exam papers.
The peon will ring the bell at 1 o'clock.
